newsitem.title: USA: USDA has team in Iowa investigating swine disease.
newsitem.headline: USDA has team in Iowa investigating swine disease.

text.p: The U.S. Agriculture Department Monday said it sent a team of veterinarians to several farms in southeastern Iowa last week to investigate a disease that has been causing sows to abort in recent months.

Joan Arnoldi, deputy administrator at USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said based on evidence so far, the disease hitting herds in Iowa and other states looks like a form of porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome (PRRS).

USDA said its team has collected blood samples and tissue from certain farms and distributed questionnares to pork producers. It will analyse the information and determine whether to visit additional farms in Iowa and other states.
The department said an updated report of the team's findings likely would be available at the Iowa Pork Congress January 21-23 in Des Moines.
The viral disease, which has affected swine in the United States, Europe and Asia since the late 1980's, causes sows to abort and causes lung lesions in all types of swine.
USDA said the course of the disease is typically two and a half months after which the herd resumes normal productivity levels.
